sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Hello and welcome to Euronews Tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Here are our top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: A new European security pact and dialogue with Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Emmanuel Macron outlines France's policy priorities while it holds the EU presidency.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: United we stand.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: US Secretary of State reassures Ukraine of unwavering Western support amid growing fears of an imminent Russian invasion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: In the name of God, go.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Boris Johnson faces calls from within his own party to resign as the so-called Partygate scandal continues to pile pressure on the British Prime Minister.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: And here in the Cube, we look at the security concerns raised about the app that will be used by athletes at the upcoming Beijing Winter Olympics.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Welcome to the programme, I'm Stefan Grober.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: President Emmanuel Macron has laid out his vision for the EU in his first speech to MEP

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: since France took over the presidency of the bloc on January the 1st.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: With escalating tensions between Ukraine and Russia amid fears of a Russian invasion, Macron urged the EU to arm itself in order to defend its interests.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: He says the EU should hold what he called frank dialogue with Moscow and seek a political solution to the ongoing crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Brussels was excluded from recent US-Russia talks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Macron says a more security-focused bloc would give them a seat at the negotiating table.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: These next few weeks must lead to a European proposal to build a new security and stability pact.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: stability pact. We must build it between Europeans before we share it with our allies within NATO and then offer it up for negotiation with Russia."

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken arrived in the Ukrainian capital Kyiv earlier for talks on the country's security concerns. Blinken came bearing messages of unity from President Joe Biden in the face of Russian aggression. He says Russia's troop buildup along Ukraine's border is a clear threat and any invasion by Moscow will result in severe consequences. President Zelensky thanked the U.S. for its support and for helping modernize its armed forces.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: PRESIDENT ZELENSKYY, U.S. There are some 100,000 Russian soldiers near Ukraine's borders, and in that sense, the threat to Ukraine is unprecedented.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So the president asked me to underscore once again our commitment to Ukraine's territorial integrity, to its sovereignty, to its independence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So our message to all of our friends here, to all of Ukraine's political leaders, to its citizens alike, is to stick together and to hold on to that unity, to strengthen it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It's never been more important, particularly as the country faces the possibility of renewed Russian aggression.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The support not only speaks to our strategic plans of Ukraine joining NATO, but more importantly to the level of our military and military supplies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Yes, we allocate the largest amounts in the budget for our military, but we still understand that if we want dramatically faster steps in modernizing the military, we need help, especially in these tough times.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Let's bring in our correspondent Grégoire Lurie, who is at the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Good evening, Greg. Good to see you. So with the Russians at the gates of Ukraine, Emmanuel Macron is asking for a new strategic rearmament of Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: How did that resonate with MEPs?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well, Stéphane, you can imagine MEPs have followed very closely the statement by Emmanuel Macron.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: I'm joined here today with David McAllister, the chair of the Foreign Affairs Committee from the EPP.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Mr. McAllister, what was your reaction to Emmanuel Macron saying that Europe should prepare for strategic rearmament?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, I was in the plenary today here in Strasbourg witnessing what the French president had to say.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And President Macron outlined the priorities of the French Presidency for this first half of 2022 and I welcome that one of the top priorities of the French Presidency is to move forward on European foreign policy but also on security and defence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And for instance the summit in March in Paris on EU defence policy will be an important step forward.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And I do hope that under the French presidency, the strategic compass can be adopted so that we kind of have a white book, a roadmap how to make concrete steps towards a European defence union.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: What's the position of the European Parliament on defence issues?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: For many years, the European Parliament has been calling for a more active and a strengthened common foreign and security policy and a common security and defence policy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The European Union is a global payer and the European Union has shown, for instance, when it comes to trade, how strong we are when we get our act together.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But we are a soft power, and that is good.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We are proud of being a soft power.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But we also need hard power capabilities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: That's why we need to move on in creating a European defence union.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We need much closer cooperation on foreign affairs, and especially on security and defence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But one thing is important for me to underline. NATO is the cornerstone of European security and all our activities should not be doubling NATO capabilities or being in competition with NATO. It's about strengthening the European pillar within the NATO framework. So perhaps you can sum it up in saying we want to remain transatlantic, we want to stay transatlantic, but on the other hand we want to become increasingly also European.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Is France got some allies on this strategic autonomy that Paris is claiming for?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: I think there's a consensus among the 27 EU member states that we have to move on if you want to call it strategic autonomy or strategic sovereignty. What all these terms have in common is that Europe needs to strengthen its capability to act and the developments in 2021 were once again a wake-up call. We have to do more for our own security and defence in close cooperation with our transatlantic partners, with the United States of America, Canada and the United Kingdom. Emmanuel Macron has targeted Russia in particular.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: This is the major threat for the EU? Well, what we're seeing in the moment is the biggest threat to European security in decades.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We as a European Union want to have good relations with Russia, but in the moment they are extremely challenged and Moscow is responsible for this. We want to see our cooperation with Russia based on the fundamental principles of European security architecture.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: That means the Helsinki Final Act, the Paris Charter, to respect the territorial sovereignty and integrity of all European countries. We are in favour of good neighbourly relations and a good rules-based cooperation respecting international law. The Kremlin and President Putin is questioning this and that's why we are in favor of continued dialogue and diplomacy with Russia but on the other hand we have to be very clear that we stand in solidarity with Ukraine that we cannot accept bullying or even the threatening of a military aggression against a sovereign country and Putin, President Putin needs to know that a military aggression against a sovereign country. And Putin, President Putin needs to know that a military aggression against Ukraine would have enormous economic consequences for Moscow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: President Macron's President- Well, thank you very much, David McAllister.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: That was the position from what we could hear from the European Parliament after Emmanuel Macron's statement on security issues.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: President Macron's President- All right.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Thank you very much, Grigory at the European Parliament in Strasbourg. To go deeper on this, I'm now joined by Oryzia Lucevich, head of the Ukraine

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Forum at Chatham House in London. Good evening and thanks for coming on the show. So, Blinken again pledged more military assistance to Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: To what extent will that enable Ukraine to withstand Russian aggression?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: I think Secretary Blinken and President Zelensky clearly underscored the need to build Ukraine's resilience to Russian encroachment and full-spectrum warfare that the Kremlin is unveiling in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And, obviously, any new military assistance that will build Ukraine's defensive capabilities will inflict more cost on Russia and hopefully will make Kremlin think twice about further incursion into new Ukrainian territory or even malicious cyber strikes, cyber attacks like we have seen this time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So this assistance is critical, and time is short.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So United States has to walk the talk and support Ukraine as much as it can to defend itself.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, at the end of the day, Western support will boil down to this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Who among NATO countries is willing and prepared to send boots on the ground to Ukraine?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well, Stefan, I think you're right that it will be a coalition of the willing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Of course, it is key that the Western allies preserve transatlantic unity and countries like the United Kingdom, the United States, eastern block of NATO member states such as Poland, Baltic states, they definitely have more resolve to get more actively involved in deterring Russia from Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And some countries, such as Germany and possibly France, are more shy about it. That is why I think it's important that part of the French presidency is this genuine dialogue, what European member states are willing to contribute. And there could be a variety of contributions. But the question is, do they perceive Russia as a threat to a similar extent as Poland compared to Portugal or even France?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So it's an important internal dialogue that is tested right now in Ukraine with Russian likelihood of military aggression.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: All right, Orizia Lutzevich, thank you so much from Chatham House, of course.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Thanks for being on the show.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Boris Johnson faced another grueling prime minister's questions as he tried to defend his position and deflect calls for his resignation as the scandal over the so-called party gate sees him fighting for his political life.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: More of those calls are now coming from within his own Conservative Party, and one of his own MPs has defected to the opposition Labour Party.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The Prime Minister was put under intense pressure again from Labour leader Keir Starmer, who said Johnson was trying to defend the indefensible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It requires the Prime Minister to expect us to believe that whilst every other person yn ddiffensibl. Mae'n gofyn i'r Prif Weinidog gofyn i ni credu bod pob person arall sy'n cael ei gyflwyno ar 20 Fawr i'r parti wedi cael ei ddweud ei fod yn ddigwyddiad cymdeithasol, ond ei hun wedi cael ei ddweud ei fod yn gweithgaredd gwaith. Mae'n gofyn i'r Prif Weinidog gofyn i ni ddychmygu ei fod wedi gwneud yn ymdrin â'r botlau a'r to ask us to accept that as he waded through the empty bottles and platters of sandwiches he didn't realize it was a party. Just the Prime Minister realized how ridiculous that sounds.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Central to the main line of defense for Boris Johnson over the party held on May 20th is that he didn't know it was a party.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: He also claims to not have been aware of any concerns his staff had over the holding of it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Something that's been directly disputed by at least two people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Keir Starmer pushed him to tell Parliament what he knew and when.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: I'm grateful to Rinaldo for repeating the question that he's already asked. Rwy'n ddiolch i Robert Jumper am ailadrodd y cwestiwn y mae wedi'i gadael. Rydyn ni wedi ateb y cwestiwn, Brif Weinidog, ac mae'n rhaid i'r cyfweliad ddod ymlaen â chyflawniad o beth sydd wedi digwydd. Rwy'n ofal bod yn rhaid i mi wneud hynny.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Ond mae'n gofyn am fy staff, Brif Weinidog. Mae'n gofyn am fy staff a'r hyn y mae'r staff yn ei wneud, a'r hyn y maen nhw wedi'i ddweud i mi. Rwy'n gallu ddweud iddo, Brif Weinidog, he asks about my staff and what my staff are doing and what they have told me. And I can tell him, Mr. Speaker, that they have taken decisions throughout this pandemic that he has opposed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: A lot to unpack here. Let's go to our reporter, Tyke Enright in London. Good evening, Tyke.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So we had a major Tory figure calling on Johnson to just go.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Another Tory defecting to Labour. Is Johnson's ship starting to sink?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Hi, Stefan. Well, yes, the ship Boris Johnson sprung a leak before Christmas when the revelations of these parties started to emerge.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And there's been a list of damaging leaks to journalists about other parties ever since and yes I think where we are right now there is every chance that Johnson could go under not just because of the holding of these parties during lockdown when we were supposed to be staying at home and staying away from other people but also because of the apparent lies that he's told in seeking to cover them up.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Last month he told Parliament that there were no parties and no rules were broken. Now we know that there were indeed parties and that indeed Boris Johnson went to one of them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So after a pretty disastrous TV interview on Tuesday, a group of relatively recently elected MPs within the Conservative Party started to coordinate their moves against him and yes you mentioned there that political bomb that went off around the time of Prime Minister's questions with one of the Conservative MPs defecting to the Labour Party and a party grandee telling him for the love of God just go. So there is a process in train, MPs who want him gone have been writing letters of no confidence to an internal Conservative Party committee. It is a secret process, but several MPs have publicly declared that they've written such letters, and we know that other MPs have been doing likewise. There's a magic number of 54 such letters have to be written before you trigger this process, at which point there will be a formal vote of no confidence in Boris Johnson. If he loses that, he's gone. But if he actually gets through that, then he can't face that process again. He's immune from that process for a further 12 months.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So those who do want him to go will have to be careful, have to be strategic in the timing of when they trigger that process. Do they do it now? Do they wait for that report by the civil servant, Sue Gray, to ascertain whether indeed these parties were illegal or not? All the while, Boris Johnson is trying to move the narrative on by also announcing today that most COVID restrictions, the same type of restrictions he's accused of breaking are being lifted.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Yeah, so if Boris Johnson is forced out, if, who is waiting in the wings to replace him?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Well, speculation is centering mainly on two figures. The current finance minister, Rishi Sunak, he's a very slick operator, his ambitions are clear to see for the top job, and who's been pretty lukewarm in his support for Boris Johnson when he's been speaking about it in recent days. Also the Foreign Minister Liz Truss, she's clearly been on manoeuvres for the top job for some time as well. Both those figures though are of course within the Cabinet and they're not openly running at this stage. One though who has tentatively thrown his hat in the ring or certainly said that he might run is Jeremy Hunt, a former health minister who came second in the last leadership race to Boris Johnson. He said he could be convinced to run again. He's a much more moderate force but you know the party does remain quite divided along kind of Brexit leave-remain lines between moderates and those on the right-hand side of the party.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And I think at this stage, you couldn't say that there would be any clear favourite to succeed Boris Johnson.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And that perhaps is part of the reason which is holding some MPs back from actually starting this process.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Stefan?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: All right. Taige Enright there in in London as always. Thank you very much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Just over two weeks before the Beijing Winter Olympics begin, fresh concerns have been raised over athlete security. A data watchdog says it's identified serious flaws in an app that will be used by participants at the upcoming Games. But the International Olympic Committee has played down the report.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Matthew in the Cube has more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, Stefan, My2022 is the app that is going to be widely available for athletes and journalists at the upcoming Beijing Winter Olympics.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: This is what the app looks like, and it predominantly serves to protect China and prevent any outbreaks of the virus during the COVID-19 pandemic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: People who are participating in the Games have been encouraged to download this app two weeks before they travel.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: And this means entering sensitive health information, not just their passport number, but also their vaccination status and of course their country of origin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: And this week there have been fresh concerns about athletes' data privacy and potential surveillance at the upcoming Games.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: The Canadian research group known as Citizen Lab have published a report saying that they have identified several security flaws within the My2022 app.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: They said that the data of athletes could be accessed by hackers and also that when athletes go to for example Beijing hotels, Olympic venues or airports and use the Wi-Fi there, then their information might also be available to the companies that provide an internet service.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Citizen Lab also said that they have identified some political topics that have been censored from discussion within the app's chat rooms.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: This report has been responded to by the International Olympic Committee.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: They have dismissed these allegations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: They say that they have had two independent cybersecurity firms examine My2022 and that neither of them have found any critical vulnerabilities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The International Olympic Committee have also said that athletes are not going to have to download this app and also that it is there to protect their health during the upcoming games.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: But on top of this you have a number of countries like the United Kingdom, the United States, Germany and the Netherlands who have all reportedly told their athletes not to take their normal phones to Beijing but instead to take temporary phones that don't store their personal data. Other countries of course have taken part in a diplomatic boycott of the Games over China's alleged human rights breaches. And on top of this all Stefan you have other human rights organizations warning athletes not to speak up and raise awareness for any issues either online or offline that go beyond the rules of the International Olympic Committee.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Aid from neighboring Australia and New Zealand is on its way to the devastated Pacific island

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: nation of Tonga.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Water supplies, shelter and the repair of critical infrastructure are top priorities as the islands try to recover following Saturday's tsunami.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Images show a blanket of volcanic ash across large areas where buildings and roads have been destroyed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: At least three people are known to have been killed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Heather Donald reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Tonga is evacuating at least 150 residents from its islands that were most affected by the volcanic eruption and following tsunami.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: They will be moved to some of the less impacted islands. The tsunami waves have caused serious damage to many of the islands and ash has covered the general area.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Communications, both national and international, have been severed due to damage sustained by the submarine cables. The internet remains down as of this morning and only as of yesterday some slight communication was established with some of the outer islands through satellite phones and and HF radios. New Zealand has so far sent two Navy ships to help with aid efforts and it has pledged around 600,000 euros towards recovery relief. For the people of Tonga, we're heading their way now with a whole lot of water.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The ship currently holds over 250,000 litres of water and we'll be able to provide that once we arrive.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: There have been three reported fatalities so far and multiple injuries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The 15-metre waves have destroyed homes, businesses and an entire village.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Most COVID-19 restrictions in England will be lifted from next week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Prime Minister Boris Johnson says people will no longer have to wear masks in closed spaces, work home or prove they've been vaccinated in order to enter public spaces.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The move follows a reduction of daily coronavirus infections. work home or prove they've been vaccinated in order to enter public spaces.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The move follows a reduction of daily coronavirus infections.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Germany has reached 100,000 new daily cases of COVID-19 for the first time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Queues of people have been growing outside testing centers with waiting times up to more than an hour.
